results.title: Free to Move
results.creator_credit: Southern Films, Schools Council, Derek Monk, Ted Channell and Brian Lewis
results.brief_description: Attempts to show that physical education is concerned with the education of the whole child, not only his physical well being. Shows need for a broad based and varied programme of activities; and how related work in other areas of the curriculum may spring from or lead to work in movement. Presents a composite picture of the balanced programme offered in a good primary school.

results.title: Free to move
results.brief_description: This video is about friction: the resistance generated when one solid surface slides in contact with another. It is also about how we reduce the forces of friction by lubrication and how lubrication controls wear, to lengthen the life of the moving parts of machinery.

results.title: Free to be, you and me
results.creator_credit: Murakami-Wolf Productions, Marlo Thomas, Carole Hart and Bill Davis
results.brief_description: A special program designed for a more structural approach to exploration of personal development concepts. Includes an all star cast from stage and screen, presenting in live action, animation and puppetry two thematically designed units: Friendship and co-operation; Expectations and independence. Features Alan Alda, Harry Belafonte, Mel Brooks, Rita Coolidge, Billy the Wolfe, Roberta Flack, Michael Jackson, Kris Kristofferson, Bobby Morse, The New Seekers, Tom Smothers, Cecily Tyson, The Voices ofo East Harlem and Dionne Warwick.

results.title: Free shadow movies
results.brief_description: Like a filmic haiku, this very short film is a series of observations of the ‘free shadow movies’ that play on the streets of everyday life. Gathering images of light, time and motion from the most simple moments - a passing train, children playing - the filmmaker has created an immersion into urban mysteries of shadow and sensation. The result, while simple and modest, is a hypnotic perception of street life as glimpsed from the corners of the eye.

results.title: Free radicals
results.brief_description:
A primitive kinetic dance of white lines and angles meticulously scratched onto black and white film over an 8 month period and then edited and retrospectively matched with an African field tape of the Bagirmi tribe. The title is a reference to modern physics, ‘free radicals’ being particles of energy. The original version was a major award winner at the Experimental Film Competition at the 1958 Brussels World Fair. This revised version was a reworking of the
original by Lye in 1979, with financial assistance from
the New Zealand Film Commission. He deleted approximately 1 min. from his first version, made in 1958.

results.title: Free play and music
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Kindergarten child series”.
Children are encouraged to select toys or materials which interest them, each child directing his own activity with the objects. Music periods involve singing accompanied by physical participation.

results.title: Free Fall
results.brief_description: With a passion for music and speedboats, Gyorgy Peto was a successful businessman from a wealthy family in the Hungarian city of Szeged. At 30 he acquired an 8mm camera and quickly become an avid and prolific home movie buff. It was 1937. Gyorgy Peto was Jewish. “Free Fall”, the tenth film in Peter Forgacs’s ongoing “Private Hungary” series, is an absolutely extraordinary look at the “ordinary” life of Peto, his family, friends and lover Eva between 1938 and 1944. As in previous films in the series, Forgacs has reworked home movies to illuminate some of the hidden interstices of mid-twentieth century Hungarian history. With Hungary a faithful ally of Nazi Germany, the Hungarian Jewish community was nevertheless virtually intact up to the spring of 1944. In the tragic and disturbing “Free Fall”, Peto’s images of the banal and tender world of family gatherings, outings on the lake, this 33rd birthday party, his lover in the bath and even of his early “merry moments” in the Jewish Labor Camps play disquietingly against radio reports, bits of newsreel footage, political speeches and the cool language of the ever more elaborate and cruel Hungarian anti-Jewish laws. The latter, chanted to a mesmerizing musical score by Tibor Szemzo, form a haunting aural counterpoint to the richly textured images of this intimate and eloquent documentary.

results.title: Free fall
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly, Colin Low and Arthur Lipsett
results.brief_description: Made of film trimmings assembled by Arthur Lipsett, this experimental film conveys a flow of intense psychological impressions representing a new form of filmed perception. Compressed into an intermittent sequence of visuals, sounds, voices and bursts of music, this film makes a wry comment on modern man and his world. It suggests a surrealist dream of mankind’s fall from grace into banality. (Awards: Montreal; San Francisco)
